name: mandarin production | mandarin | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/22076/documentation

This datasets represents the growing of mandarin inSouth Africa, high density planting (1600 tree/ha). This configuration would have a potential yield of 75 ton/ha, an average yield of 45 ton/ha, a conservative yield of 35 ton/ha. The dataset represent the production over a year of 1 kg of mandarin. For the year of reference a yield of 53,48 ton/ha has been produced. The data came from Commercial Enterprise Budget (Combuds) for mandarin cultivation from the Western Cape Department of Agriculture. Mandarin growing areas in South Africa are: Western Cape (42%), Eastern Cape (31%) and Limpopo (20%), with some minor production in Mpumalanga (4%). The dataset represent the WC province, althought the citrus farming practices are quite standardised throughout the country. ;The transport in the dataset refers to the transport in the farm stage.

This activity starts with the nursery producing tree seedlings, i.e. grafted young trees to be planted. 

This activity ends with the waste treatment after the clearing of the orchard. The dataset includes all activities of a year in a year in the productive phase of the orchard including the establishment phase per year of lifetime (25 years, 1600 trees/ha planted), the clearing of the orchard including waste treatment. 
The establishment phase of the orchard includes tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, and irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase.
The productive phase of the orchard includes machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations in the productive phase are: soil cultivation (hoeing), fertiliser and pesticide application, harvesting and irrigation. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. At the end of the productive phase the orchard is cleared by rooting up the trees and this is represented by the exchange waste wood, untreated.
Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered.
The inputs of seedlings, fertilisers (mineral) and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/012:Growing of perennial crops/0123:Growing of citrus fruits

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This datasets represents the growing of mandarin inSouth Africa, high density planting (1600 tree/ha). This configuration would have a potential yield of 75 ton/ha, an average yield of 45 ton/ha, a conservative yield of 35 ton/ha. The dataset represent the production over a year of 1 kg of mandarin. For the year of reference a yield of 53,48 ton/ha has been produced. The data came from Commercial Enterprise Budget (Combuds) for mandarin cultivation from the Western Cape Department of Agriculture. Mandarin growing areas in South Africa are: Western Cape (42%), Eastern Cape (31%) and Limpopo (20%), with some minor production in Mpumalanga (4%). The dataset represent the WC province, althought the citrus farming practices are quite standardised throughout the country.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The amount of exchanges refers to the farming activities for mandarin production in Westerc Cape Province (ZA).
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The data came from Commercial Enterprise Budget (Combuds) for mandarin cultivation from the Western Cape Department of Agriculture. Mandarin growing areas in South Africa are: Western Cape (42%), Eastern Cape (31%) and Limpopo (20%), with some minor production in Mpumalanga (4%) - CGA 2016. The dataset represent the WC province, althought the citrus farming practices are quite standardised throughout the country.

exchanges.description: Mandarin production, South Africa. The 1337 ton represents the total production of 1ha over 25 years using the yield data (53,48 ton) of the year of reference (2008). According to the ComBuds (Companies Budget reports) the yield may vary widely from a max of 75 ton/year to min of 35 ton/year. The expected value is around 45 ton/year, whilst the average is around 55 ton/year. The yield of the referce year is closer to the avearage than the expected value.

flow.name: mandarin
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/012:Growing of perennial crops/0123:Growing of citrus fruits

exchanges.description: Two inputs were considered to determin the carbon dioxide emissions associated with the farm stage of the Western Cape Mandarin: ‘Calcite-Bredrp’ and ‘Spray Urea’. The methodology used to ascertain the value of carbon dioxide released to the air from the application of two aforementioned inputs was in accord with worst case scenario approach put forward by the IPCC (2006):   Calcite-Bredrp: The carbon dioxide emission factor for limestone, as specified by IPCC (2006), was applied to this input. The value of said emission factor is 0.44 kg CO2/ kg limestone.    Spray Urea: The carbon dioxide emission factor for urea, as specified by IPCC (2006), was applied to this input. The value of said emission factor is 0.73 kg CO2/ kg N.

exchanges.description: Wood from trees after 1-2 years of sorrage at the field (20% water) per lifetime year (25 years) of the orchard. Calculated value per kg of produced mandarin: considering the volume of pruning residues of HD mandarin orchard ranges between 10-15 m3 or 5.6 - 8.4 ton/ha, a wood density of about 0.56 (g/cm3 or ton/m3) and a production yield of 53,48 ton/ha.

exchanges.description:
The ammonia emissions resulting from the application of LAN 28 % Spray Urea were estimated using emission factors detailed in EMEP/EEA guidelines (2013); 
LAN 28 %: The ammonia emission factor for calcium ammonium nitrate, as specified by EMEP/EEA (2013) is 0.18 kg N/ kg CAN applied.
Spray Urea: The ammonia emission factor for urea, as specified by EMEP/EEA (2013) is 0.20 kg N/ kg Urea applied.
Soil pH between 6 and 6.5.

flow.name: Ammonia

exchanges.description: This represent the input water that needs to be withdrawn for irrigation (blue water) Iw= ETirr/(Ea*Ec) considering that the Etirr = 352,92m3 per ton, Ea=0,9(-) and Ec=1 (-); the water stemming from precipitation is estimated in 82.6m3 per ton (green water); the latter has been calculated based on green water footprint for mandarin in Clanwilliam (WC).

exchanges.description:
Diesel use represents the summation of all the diesel use associated with onsite processes within the farm stage.  The following assumptions were used in the conversion of the inputs to MJ of diesel
- Estimated diesel input per hectare (assuming average cost per L = R6.11) this excludes cross-ploughing & delivery of irrigation & drainage material.
- Assumed 43.1 MJ/ kg of diesel according to (Wikipedia, 2014)
- Fuel emissions were not disaggregated into activities (hoeing, fence and trellis building, fertilizing and ploughing).

See 'WFLDB-Guidelines.pdf', available at https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/File/Reports.

exchanges.description: The exchange has been updated from 'potassium chloride, as K2O' into 'potassium chloride' and therefore its amount has been scaled (multiplied) from 0.005 kg by 1.5829 kg of 'potassium chloride' per kg of 'potassium chloride, as K2O'. Original comment of the exchange is: The K2O input was modelled by assuming that 60 wt% of the KCI fertilizer is directly equivalent, on a mass basis, to synthetically produced mineral K2O. Data from ComBuds for 2008 reports the following quantities of Potassium Cloride, as K2O applied: year 1 60 kg/ha; year 2 and 3 120 kg/ha per year; years 4 kg 300 kg/ha: years 5-6 300 kg/ha per year; and year 7-25 300 kg/ha per year. Total amount 276 kg/ha.

Syntheticall produced generic pesticide was modelled assuming the following:
it is directly equivalent, on a mass basis, to 41 wt% of Roundup herbicide by assuming a density of 1,172 kg/L;
it is directly equivalent, on a mass basis, to 20,5 wt% of Solubur herbicide by assuming a density of 0.4 kg/L
it is directly equivalent, on a mass basis, to 30 wt% of Chlorodosal herbicide by by assuming a density of 1.6 kg/L

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of pesticides needed for the production of mandarin is calculated to be circa 1.66E-03 kg. Pesticide/s used in this dataset is/are: '[thio]carbamate-compound', 'atrazine', 'captan', 'copper oxide', 'glyphosate', 'magnesium', 'magnesium sulfate', 'metaldehyde', 'organophosphorus-compound, unspecified', 'pesticide, unspecified', 'triazine-compound, unspecified', 'zinc oxide'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of pesticide/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 3.32E-03 kg of packaging for pesticides is justified with this exchange.

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of fertilisers needed for the production of 'mandarin' is calculated to be circa 1.56E-02 kg. Fertiliser/s used in this dataset is/are: 'lime', 'nitrogen fertiliser, as N', 'phosphate fertiliser, as P2O5', 'potassium chloride, as K2O', 'potassium nitrate', 'sodium borates', 'urea, as N'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of fertiliser/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 3.13E-02 kg of packaging for fertilisers is justified with this exchange.
